case_vignette: A 16-year-old Caucasian boy presents to your family practice office complaining of itchiness. He denies other symptoms. He also denies tobacco, alcohol, or other illicit drug use and is not sexually active. He has no other significant past medical or surgical history aside from a meniscal repair from a wrestling injury sustained two years ago from which he has recovered fully. Vitals are T 98.3, HR 67, BP 110/70. On exam you note several pruritic, erythematous, slightly raised annular patches with central clearing on his back.
question: Which  additional tests or features are sufficient to make the diagnosis of this boy's skin lesion?
correct_ans: presence of hyphae when koh added to skin scrapings

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm just feeling really itchy.
How long have you been experiencing this itchiness?
I didn't say when it started.
My apologies. When did you first notice the itchiness?
I didn't mention exactly when I first noticed the itchiness.
Got it. Could you please tell me your age and sex?
I'm a 16-year-old boy.
Do you have any history of skin conditions or allergies? Any family history of skin conditions?
I have no significant past medical history and didn't mention any allergies or family history of skin conditions.
Are you currently taking any medications?
I didn't say that I'm taking any medications.
Understood. Have you noticed any rash or redness on your skin where you feel itchy?
Yes, there are several red, slightly raised, ring-shaped patches with clear centers on my back.

Thank you. Based on your symptoms and description, it sounds like you may have **Ringworm (Tinea corporis)**.

**Final Diagnosis:** Ringworm (Tinea corporis)

I've been feeling really itchy.
Could you tell me where on your body you are feeling itchy?
The itchiness is on my back.
Have you noticed any rash or redness on your back where you are feeling itchy?
Yes, there are some red, slightly raised rings with a clear center on my back.

No, I don't have any similar rashes in the past, no known allergies, and no medical conditions, except for a knee surgery from a wrestling injury two years ago.

**Final Diagnosis:** Tinea corporis (ringworm)
